Good morning,

Let me begin by asking you a question, “Have you ever made a promise and failed to keep it?”

I have  countless times. We all have. There is no person living on earth who has not failed to keep a promise. All of us are “promise failures”.

But, there is only one, I mean one, “promise keeper” who has not, cannot and will never fail to keep his promises. And that is the Lord, God Almighty, our Heavenly Father. He is a faithful “promise maker and keeper”.

In the Bible, from Genesis to Revelation, God has made very special promises to his people which he has fulfilled throughout all generations. The Bible clearly gives us reasons why his promises cannot fail. One of them to focus on today is,

“For the promises of God in Him are YES, and in Him Amen….” (2 Cor. 1:20)
Note, only the promises of God that are in him are guaranteed. There is no but or may be. God always gives his promises with a very strong emphasis of assurance “I will….”

Have you claimed any promise or promises of God and failed to receive? I have many times. Does that mean that God failed? No. There could be several reasons why you and I fail to receive God’s promises. However, there are four major reasons why you will fail to receive.

1.) You don’t know the promises. God has a promise to take care of you in every situation. He has said that he will provide all your needs; that he will deliver you from all your afflictions,” Many are the afflictions of the righteous, but God delivers them from them all”.(Psalms 34:19); that he will not fail you; that he will heal, strengthen, protect, promote you; that he will never fail you or let you be a shamed; that if you call on him He will answer and do to you great and mighty things you have not known or imagined (Jeremiah 33:1, 32:27). The list goes on. Are you aware of the specific promises for your specific problems and needs? Go to the Manual-the Bible and find out.
2.) You have not claimed the promises. God’s promises are to be claimed. Just like you must present a check to the bank to claim promised cash, likewise you must identify God’s promise and claim it. He says, “Ask it shall be given you. You don’t ask, you don’t get.
3.) You don’t believe the promise. Knowing and asking without believing the promise and trusting that God will honor the promise will not do you any good. A lot of people make a lot of claims in their prayers, but don’t believe what they are claiming is possible. If you don’t believe, you cannot receive.
4.) You don’t wait for God to fulfill his promises his way in his time. Impatience can be very costly. Waiting is the hardest thing for many of us and impatience is one of the major hindrances to fulfillment to God’s promises.  After you have claimed God’s promise, you better be prepared to wait until….God cannot let you down. People will let you down but God will lift you up. Your circumstances will tear you a part but God will put your torn pieces  together. You can never fail or falter if you make a claim that is good, acceptable and is perfect will God, rest assured that God will fulfill his WORD. (Romans 12:1-2)

There are two very obvious observations you will make when reading your Bible, 1) that it is a book that has real life stories of men and women, families, nations, prophets, disciples, kings and rulers, young men and old men, who loved God with all their hearts and worshipped him in truth and the Holy Ghost, but who were all greatly afflicted by all kinds of afflictions, 2) that is a Great Book full of God’s promises and  that God faithfully fulfilled those promises in the lives of all those who claimed them in their afflictions.

Thriving on God’s Promises
God is a promise keeping God. What he promises you, he will do even when you are not faithful in keeping your promise to him. The Bible is sacred book from your heavenly father. It is the source of God’s promises to you. From Genesis to Revelation, God declares, at times, solemnly what he will do without fail. One thing is sure, he has promised to deliver the righteous from, “all their problems.”

“Many are the afflictions of the righteous, but God delivers them from them all”.(Psalms 34:19)

Rise up, study the promises, claim them, believe them, and wait upon God. Stand still and you will see the salvation of the Lord (Exodus 14:13)
Rejoice for all things are yours for today, not tomorrow, is your day of blessings. May God bless and keep you. Brother Boaz

title.rendered: What and what not to do faced with a problem

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Don’t magnify your problems
Your problems are only as big as you want them to be. How you see your problems will depend on what lenses you have on. If you have God’s lenses, you will see them as nothing or insignificant hills instead of as impossible to climb high mountains.

God does not expect you to solve your own problems with your might and ingenuity. Zerubbabel thought he would solve his own problems using his power and personal might. He was wrong. It was a bad move. When God saw his desperate and unsuccessful attempts, he sent word to him through Zechariah and said, “Not by might nor by power, but by my Spirit, says the Lord Almighty.” (Zechariah 4:6) There was an assurance that God would solve his problem. Immediately, he changed his attitude toward the “mountain of a problem” he faced and put on new lenses and took a look at his problem again, disrespectfully, and sized the problem accordingly. He then talked to the problem face to face and demanded to know its origin and identity by asking by asking, “Who are you, big mountain? He followed the question by making a declaration, “In front of Zerubbabel, you will become a flat land, and he will bring the topmost stone, shouting! g, ‘It’s beautiful! It’s beautiful!” (Zechariah 4:7)

Don’t Go Down to Egypt for Help Five
“Woe to them that go down to Egypt for help; and stay on horses, and trust in chariots, because they are very strong; but they look not unto the Holy One (God) of Israel, neither seek the Lord! Yet he also is wise, and will bring evil, and will not call back his words; but will arise against the house of evil doers, and against the help of them that work iniquity. Now the Egyptians are men, and not God; and their horses flesh, and not spirit. When the Lord shall stretch out his hand, both he that helpeth shall fall, and he that is holpen shall fall down, and they all shall fall together.” (Isaiah 32:1-3, KJV)

Psalms 37: 3-8 lists five vital biblical counsels for successful living and also provides guidelines for dealing with any problem in life:
Trust in the Lord
Delight yourself also in the Lord
Commit your way unto the Lord
Rest in the Lord and wait patiently for him
5.  Cease from anger, and forsake wrath

Think, and meditate on these time tested and proven wise counsel and see how your problems will melt right before your eyes not by your might but by His Spirit. God bless you and have a blessed day. Brother Boaz

Good morning,

“But the LORD God called to the man, “Where are you?” Genesis 3:9

Have you ever gotten lost?  I am famous for getting lost, and thank God my wife is the family GPS.  Unlike most men I have stopped at many gas stations to ask directions and am not ashamed to do so, because I would rather be sure that I am heading in the right direction then to drive down the highway hoping I am going in the right direction.  I think we have all been lost at some point in our lives.  Furthermore, we become lost at times, not so much driving on man made roads and highways, but on the road of life.  And this is precisely where Adam found himself when he chose to sin against God.  Adam ran and hid from the LORD God among the trees of the garden.

David wrote in Ps 139 “You know when I sit and when I rise; you perceive my thoughts from afar. You discern my going out and my lying down;…Where can I go from your Spirit? Where can I flee from your presence?”  Did Adam really think he could hide from GOD?!  Sin had such an affect on Adam’s mind that he thought that God would not be able to see him among the trees of the garden.  God created Adam and the tree, and the Creator could easily see all of His creation.  Then God asked the questions, ADAM WHERE ARE YOU?  God certainly wasn’t asking for Adam to name his coordinates upon the earth or in the Garden.  What then was God asking when he asked Adam WHERE ARE YOU?

Where are you in your thinking?  Did you really think you could hide from Me?  I am your Creator who knows and sees all, where are you in your thoughts that you have forgotten this?  Where are you in applying my truth to your life?

2.    Where are you in your relationship with Me?  You have never tried to hide anything from me, why would you start now?  We communed together in the cool of the day, and now where are you during the time that is our time?  Were you spending times with, talking and taking orders from others when it was our time together?

3.    Where are you in your family leadership?  I created you first to be the protector of Eve, but what happened when she was assaulted by the serpent, where was your manhood at that time?  Where are you as a protector and provider of Eve?  Where was your leadership when Eve needed you?  You became a follower, taking the fruit from her, instead of guiding her by your leadership and standing in the gap at the time of her assault.

4.    Where are you in your obedience?  I told you to obey me, and that the whole Garden was yours to use and cultivate, the animals was for you to name.  The serpent challenged my words, and when he did where was your obedience?

Where are you today in your thinking, relationship with God, your family leadership, and in your obedience to Him?  Men, notice that God asked ADAM not Eve WHERE ARE YOU.  Men we need to take our responsibility as men to saturate our minds with God’s Word, cultivate our relationship with God and lead our families.  We need to obey Him even when disobedience seems more enticing.  God is asking His children WHERE ARE YOU!?!?!?  Spend some time today and let the Holy Spirit search you, then do what you know you must do, and God will never let you down.     Until the nets are filled…Blessings, Pastor Phil

Good morning,

After 2,000 years, a seed from ancient Judea sprouts. Israeli doctors and scientists have succeeded in germinating a date seed nearly 2,000 years old. The seed nicknamed Methuselah, was taken from excavation at Masada, the cliff fortress where, in A.D. 73, 960 Jewish zealots died by their own hand, rather than surrender to a Roman assault…The plant is now 11.8 inches tall and has produced seven leaves…Dates need to grow 30 years to reach maturity and can leave as long as 200 years. The original date palm of Judea is praised in the Bible and the Koran for its shade, food, beauty and medicinal qualities. (From news article, “After 2,000 Years, a Seed from Ancient Judea Sprouts” written by Steven Erlanger and reported in The New York Times of June12, 2005) Seeds have life and some, like the date, can live for centuries and still be germinated. That is amazing. When I read this news, I began to think about the believers and the seeds that we sow everyday. I found out that the Bible compares the righteous and their seeds to the palm tree and its seeds. “The righteous shall flourish like the palm tree, “says Psalms 92.” “They shall still bring forth fruit in old age. They shall be fat and flourishing.”

Everything we have in our possession are seeds that God has given to us to use and share with others and God. When we do that, we are planting seeds so we can expect more harvest.  Examples of such seeds include but not are limited to:  seeds of prayers, faith, worship, praise, love, gifts, encouragement, care, money, food, friendship, clothing, hospitality witnessing, care, leadership, discipline, preaching, teaching, knowledge etc. Have you been sowing seeds for many years and you have wondered why some of them did not sprout and grow for you to harvest. Some probably took so long you even forgot about them. In the cause of time, you might have doubted and may be you have been discouraged from sowing anymore. Well, if that has been your experience, it is not uncommon and you are not the odd one out. Your experience mimics many of us experience. But, I have news for you, “All the seeds you have sown, from whatever time, are a live and well, and will soon germinate and produce a mighty harvest for you. None of the seeds you have sow in good soil have died. They might have been dormant, but not dead. The Spirit of God is going to quicken them in due season and they will sprout and grow into a hundredfold for you to harvest for your enjoyment and glorification of God and further seeding. Expect a miracle harvest! A time of harvesting is guaranteed by God in his holy and unfailing word-the Bible.

“They that sow in tears shall reap in joy (Psalms 126:5). He that goes forth and weeps, bearing precious seed, shall doubtless come again with rejoicing, bringing his sheaves with him.” (Vse.6)

In Genesis 8:22, God vowed, “While the earth remain, seedtime and harvest, and cold and heat, and summer and winter, and day and night shall not cease (end).
Some of your prayer seed might have taken longer that you expected to be answered. Wait. The answer is on the way. Help is on the way. Whatever it is you are expecting: a wife or husband, peaceful and fulfilling marriage, disciplined and blessed children, family salvation and unity, opportunity for further education, promotion, a new and better paying job, healing, money, house, food, school fees, rent, restored relationship, victory over difficult, challenging and threatening circumstances, healing form incurable or terminal disease, God’s peace, comfort, direction and presence, in your troubled life, etc.

If you have sown seeds of prayer of faith, wait patiently upon God. Your seeds are about to germinate. Some may take 1, 5, 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, or even a hundred years before germinating, but eventually all seeds will sprout. Let this be your faith, hope and confidence. I have waited for many years for many things I prayed for and believed God to provide. It took 30 years for God to revel my eldest son’s wife to be and we are now preparing for a mighty weeding harvest next year. My daughter just got married in September of this year. It was a blessed and great weeding that I prayed for and saw over twenty years ago. I waited 9 years to graduate from college with a bachelor degree at age 37, and another 15 years later to complete a Masters degree at 52. What I didn’t tell you is, “I was a high school failure who didn’t qualify for further education opportunity in a country that had only three universities at the time.” I waited 10 years for our faith seed to germinate into a beautiful house in the mountains; waited seven years for God to bring my family of nine from Africa to the United States and unite us and prosper us the way he has done. God is able! “The Lord has done great things for us; wherefore we are glad” (Psalms 126:3). My friend, trust God; he will do likewise to you, even much more. Continue to water your gardens with praise and thanksgiving; look up expectantly; continue sowing your seeds whenever you have opportunity; do not be afraid of anything; God is in control. Expect a miracle harvest, starting from today. God bless you.
Boaz Olang

title.rendered: Fed By Obeying His Will, By Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

“But he said to them, “I have food to eat that you know nothing about.” “My food,” said Jesus, “is to do the will of him who sent me and to finish his work.” (John 4:32,34)

Have you ever tried to share something with someone and they just didn’t comprehend what you were saying?  Jesus seemed to run into that situation often, even though He was a Master communicator.  Jesus had just finished having a conversation with the women at the well, when his disciples were approaching with lunch.   His disciples “were surprised to find him talking with a woman.”  It was considered improper for a Rabbi to speak with women in public, let alone one that was sexually immoral.  The disciples see the women leave, and see her water bucket that she left as evidence of her presence, and not “just their imaginations.”  But no one asked, ‘What do you want?’ or ‘Why are you talking with her?’  I believe, that although no one asked those questions, those were the questions that they had on their minds.

His disciples have these questions, but didn’t dare ask them.  Therefore, what do men do when they don’t want to speak about what is really on their minds?  They eat!  Eating doesn’t take much brain power, similar to watching TV.  They urged Jesus, “Rabbi, eat something.”  Jesus however knowing their thoughts replies, “I have food to eat that you know nothing about.”  Now they are thinking that someone came and gave Jesus food.   Jesus continues by saying, “My food,” said Jesus, “is to do the will of him who sent me and to finish his work.”  Now they were really thrown off.  What was Jesus getting at, because they were talking about food, but Jesus wasn’t talking about food, He was talking about FOOD!  What was this food?

The fulfillment Jesus just has with ministering to the lost women.

2.    The overall life mission of reconciling the world to the Father through Himself as the bridge.

3.    The sustenance of pleasing His Father by obeying the mission that He gave Jesus to live out.

4.    The very hunger He possessed, they did not yet crave, and that is being salt to make sinners thirsty for the water that the women received.

What was the work Jesus was to finish?  Just as drinking from the well would cause the women to thirst again, so too will the disciples hunger again if their food source was from town supermarket.  The women needed the living water, and the disciples needed the bread of life, and the desire to seek and save the lost just as Jesus had.  When the women was filled with the water of life she began to bring others to Jesus, and that is what Jesus was looking for in His Twelve.    “Do you not say, ‘Four months more and then the harvest’? I tell you, open your eyes and look at the fields! They are ripe for harvest. 36 Even now the reaper draws his wages, even now he harvests the crop for eternal life, so that the sower and the reaper may be glad together. 37 Thus the saying ‘One sows and another reaps’ is true. 38 I sent you to reap what you have not worked for. Others have done the hard work, and you have reaped the benefits of their labor.”  Jesus wanted the eyes of the disciples opened to the fields, NOT to their “food!” Job said, “I have treasured the words of his mouth more than my daily bread.”  Jesus said told you and me to seek and save the lost.  When we obey God in this, we too will eat the food that many do not know of.  Are you hungry?  Go to the harvest fields of your schools and jobs, and finish the work by the power of the Holy Spirit, and be fed by obeying His will!

Until the nets are filled…Blessings, Pastor Phil

title.rendered: Who are you in the Kingdom of God?

content.rendered:
Good morning,

“My people are destroyed for of lack of knowledge (in other words because of ignorance): Because thou hast rejected knowledge, I will also reject thee….” (Hosea 4:6)
What you don’t know can destroy you or deprive you of what is rightfully yours. Ignorance has no defense, someone once said.

Today, I would like to expose you to some fundamental biblical knowledge (truth) to meditate on that will help you understand and know your true self (person). Knowing who you are and whose you are is the key to your rightful position and possessions in the kingdom of God. Your life cannot be meaningful, happy, satisfying and complete in this world without you fully understanding, from the Bible’s point of view, what God has done for you; what position God has put you and; what possessions you are entitled to as a child of God. God’s children have rights, privileges, favors, and blessings that are not available to everybody.

Who are you in the Kingdom of God? What is your relationship with God? If you don’t have a relationship with God, you don’t have a right to any of his blessings.

If you are born again, then you are a child of God. You have been empowered to be a bon-fide, legitimate child of God. God’s blood is running in your veins and any spiritual DNA test will reveal that you have a relationship with Christ. The Bible confirms that.

“He came to his own, and his own received him not. But as many as received him, to them gave he power to become the sons of God, even to them that believe on his name. Which were born, not of blood, nor of the will of the flesh, nor of the will of man, but of God. (John 1:11-13)

“Blessed be the God and Father of our Lord and Jesus Christ, which according to his abundant mercy has begotten us again unto a lively hope by the resurrection of Jesus Christ from the dead….” (1Peter 1:3)
The new relationship is a favor, privilege, blessing and honor that God has extended to all of us who were ones nothing but sinners destined for hell. For all have sinned and fallen short of God’s glory (Romans 3:23).

But he has chosen you and translated you from servant-hood to sonship. Jesus said to his disciples whom he had empowered to become children of God just like you and I,
“…Hence forth I call you not servants; for the servant does not know what his Lord does;…Ye have not chosen me, but I have chosen you and ordained YOU ….” (John 15:15-16)

Rise up today; think, walk, talk, act and live like a true child of God. Forget about your temporary misery, problems, challenges or lack. You have everything in Christ. Let not the lies of Satan confuse you. Stand and declare what is written. Praise God and rejoice over your new relationship with him. Amen! God bless you. Boaz

Good morning friends,

John 11:44, “And he that was dead came forth, bound hand and foot with grave clothes: and his face was bound about with a napkin”
You may have read at one point the story of Lazarus brought back to life. This is a man who was close to Jesus and at one point he became so sick while Jesus was a way and finally he died. I don’t want to dwell on what happened from the time that he died to the time that Jesus calls him out of the grave, I want to dwell on the his condition when he came out. When one gets saved, he is brought back to life just like Lazarus who died and brought back to life. When brought back to life marks the beginning of work in that person’s life that he or she may be complete.
Lazarus is brought back to life but there is one little problem, he is bound by grave clothes. The clothes they buried him in is coiled around him like a band aid that he cannot see, breathe well, move, hear or even stand steadily. Yes he is a live but still has issues that needs to be dealt with. title.rendered: What is Written of You?, By Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

“And Moses wrote their goings out according to their journeys by the commandment of the Lord:  And these are their journeys according to their going out.” Number 33:2

Many people record many things in this life.  In looking at the Guinness Book of World Records you will discover that it records some of the craziest things that people have done.

Moses recorded all the places that Israel pitched their tents.  Each place had its ups and downs, positives and negatives, yet they pitched their tents anyhow. Think for a moment of the Tabernacle of Witness, which had as its purpose to be in the middle of tribes as a witness of God’s presence as they traveled.  John 1:14 states, that Jesus Christ came and “tabernacled among us.”  And what was further written of the life of Christ was that He would bring redemption paid for by His blood.  Why, because His mission was to seek and to save the lost.

Is our mission any different?  Now the whole being the Redeemer of Israel could only go to Christ, but His mission of seeking and saving the lost is still ours as a continuation of what He began.  We need to go in the power of the Holy Spirit obeying the mission so that Heaven’s recordings of our lives show that we pitched our tents and shared the gospel with the lost on our way to the Promised Land of Heaven.

What will be written of you or what do you think has been written already about your pitching your tent to reach the unsaved?  We are called to be living epistles read of by men.  “You are our epistle (letter) written in our hearts, known and read of all men…written not with ink buy with the Spirit of the living God; not in tables of stone, but in fleshly tables of the heart.” (2 Cor. 3:2-3)  Our very lives in Christ are results of God’s grace upon us giving us salvation instead of condemnation.

We have therefore become a letter for all to read, we are walking testimonials.  But to bring balance let us NEVER FORGET that we are called to be “living letters” called to speak the word and truth of God, (Rom 10:13-15), because “they” can’t hear unless you speak.  Now yes have your walk match your talk, that is to say live a godly lifestyle, but don’t take a vow of silence!  Ray Comfort speaks of “monasteries without walls,” to describe any Christian who leaves their church on Sunday, goes home and does nothing for Christ, then returns the following Sunday to “rejoice in the Lord.”  Such Christians have extended their monastery without walls and keep a vow of silence about Jesus Christ in their sphere of influence.  If we do this, then we deserve the evil that is coming to our nation, for we seek no way to use the only change agent, THE PREACHED GOSPEL!  That is why only 2% of Christians, even 2% of you who receive these devotions actively share the gospel.  You were saved to serve, end of story.

If we claim to be a living letter, why then are we not pitching our tents (lives) daily to share the gospel with those around us?  What will Heaven write about how you pitched your tent?  Will your tent be pitched for food, fun, and fellowship (the great disguising mark of most churches), or perhaps your pages will be blank because this book will record what is done to further “the kingdom by force”. Perhaps it will it be written of you that you pitched your tent for furthering the gospel?  Israel pitched their tents in all kinds of situations, and we are called to do the same.  If you like your job or not, if you like your school or not, remember, we are not here for ourselves, we are saved to serve.

Application: “Woe to me if I preach not the gospel.” (1 Cor. 9:6)

content.rendered:
Good morning,

“Yea, though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death, I shall fear no evil: for though at with me; thy rod and thy staff they comfort me (Psalms 23:4).

Fear is a dreadful disease, which is why it is capable of killing its victims, in some cases, much faster than some of the dreadful diseases of our time such as cancer, AIDS and heart attack. It is a disease with no pathological cause but it is real and it preys on all of us. Most of our failures and maladies are caused by it.

Fear is also paralyzing. It is limiting and debilitating. Fear is capable of defeating good intentions and purposes. If not conquered, fear conquers and controls. Fear is capable of intensifying and is equally explosive. Too much of it is dangerous. None of it is abnormal. Mild fear or intense fear, depending on the situation, is necessary for healthy living. Fear can motivate us to do something more than we ordinarily would do. Fear can also trigger a positive change. We, therefore, should experience some fear; healthy fear.

However, chronic fear will definitely trigger failure in any area of your life.

As believers how can we avoid being ruled and controlled by fear? How can we overcome fear when we are suddenly under its grip? How can we fight fear? What weapons do we need for attacking and defeating fear? How can we respond to situations and circumstances that cause fear in our lives? Whom can we rely on to overcome frightful and deadly effects of fear? What can happen to us if we do not overcome fear?  What is fear anyway?

David, the author of Psalms 23, had more reasons to fear than most of us. On many occasions, Soul sought to kill him. At times, he spent time in caves and in deserted places running away from Saul. He also made mistakes whose consequences left him worried and fearful. How did he overcome his fears?

He learned to confess who God was to him; he learned to affirm God’s presence with him; he made a conscious decision not to fear any evil.

If you too want to overcome any fear in your life, know who God is to you personally. To David, he was, “my Shepard”. Declare that his presence is with you at all times and in all situations. To David, that was key truth that gave him peace and reassured him that all was well with him. He said of God, “thou at with me; thy rod and thy staff they comfort me”. Today, confess loudly:

“Yea, though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death, I shall fear no evil…” (Vs.4). Do that every time the spirit of fear creeps around. Resist and defeat the devil by the blood of the Lamb and by the Word of your testimony (confession) (Revelation 12:11). God bless you. Boaz

title.rendered: Leveled at the Throne – Part 2, By David Jackson and Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

The body is a unit, though it is made up of many parts; and though all its parts are many, they form one body. So it is with Christ. 1 Cor. 12:12

In part 1 of Leveled at the Throne, we looked at Revelation 7:9-10, how at the Throne of Grace on that Great Day there will be “a great multitude that no one could count, from every nation, tribe, people and language, standing before the throne and in front of the Lamb.”  This is where all the nations bow before their Sovereign King.  However before we are in heaven together, we are to be one body with many parts, which is to say God wants to use our differences under His command.  David Jackson shares his personal experience and illustrates this point well.

I spent time in the army. As you know- there are the marines, air force, army, navy, coast guard. Each branch is diverse. The ARMY way is not the navy way- thank you, Jesus! Each service has its own proud traditions that they would rather keep and not defer to the others. So, where does the unity come from? The commander in chief! The services are united in him. Each service conducts its exercises without input from the others- and sometimes- it interferes or frustrates the work of the others. Each service has its own way of doing things UNTIL they look to and respond to the commander in chief. He coordinates their efforts and brings about the unity necessary to establish strategic and tactical advantages. I wouldn’t dare work with somebody in the navy. The navy way is to fight from boats instead of facing the enemy in mortal combat on the ground- face to face- man to man (the ARMY way). There’s anonymity to fighting on boats- you gotta do things as a group. BUT the ARMY way is up close and personal. You can’t win a war with navies because navies can’t occupy lands. Wars are declared and waged on land. Now, they do have some; albeit, little- use to the Army. They can transport more of us than the air force- although transport is slower. I won’t even talk about how weak they are physically and how they’re uniforms are for girly. (If you talked to somebody from the other services, I’m sure they have silly criticisms of the army…he-he-he-he)

BUT when the commander in chief calls us into action- for a time- we suspend such distinctives and yield to his wisdom and superintendence. We accommodate and work with each other acknowledging the other’s importance, accepting/appreciating the other’s distinctiveness, and mitigating the other’s limitations. Only then, can we work to accomplish the will of the commander.

I find that people must realize their distinctiveness and use their uniqueness to benefit everyone. When we look to Jesus, we can defer to others; we don’t have to lose ourselves- just join ourselves to the larger goal of Christ alongside others.

Are you using your distinctiveness and uniqueness to add or take away from everyone in the body?  Can you look to your Commander in Chief for your marching orders, accommodating and working alongside other believers acknowledging, and even appreciating their differences for the bigger picture in mind?

Good morning,

We apologize for the delay in bringing devotions.

An old man was picking up objects off the beach and tossing them out into the sea. A young man approached him and saw that the objects were starfish. “Why in the world are you throwing starfish into the water?”
“If the starfish are still on the beach when the tide goes out and the sun rises high in the sky, they will die,” replied the old man.

The wise old man picked up another starfish, paused thoughtfully, and remarked as he tossed it out into the waves,

“It makes a difference to this one.”
From The Star Thrower (1979) by Loren Eiseley.

This story illustrates the love, concern and care God has shown to those of us who have been saved by grace. Like the star fish, we had been washed a shore and left to die under the scourging heat of sin. If you are saved, thank God today for your salvation and remember that you are very special. He made a difference in your life so you too can make a difference in other’s lives, even if it is just one life. If you have not received him as Lord and savior, you are like the washed star fish on the sea shore. If you are not picked and thrown back to the sea of life, you will die. Don’t let that happen to you. Allow Jesus to pick you up and save you. Do not resist and procrastinate. Like the dying star fish at the shore, you don’t have much time to live. Today is the day of salvation.

“What lies behind us and what lies before us are little matters compared to what lies within us”. R. W. Emerson

God bless you and have a great day. Boaz

Good morning,

“After this I looked and there before me was a great multitude that no one could count, from every nation, tribe, people and language, standing before the throne and in front of the Lamb. They were wearing white robes and were holding palm branches in their hands. And they cried out in a loud voice: “Salvation belongs to our God, who sits on the throne, and to the Lamb.” Revelation 7:9-10

When I think of this passage of Scripture I must remember that it was written by John the Revelator.  Jesus gave John a revelation when John was abandoned to the Isle of Patmos, A.D. 63, and hence we get the book of Revelation.

I recently saw a theater play concerning diversity and racial unity.  It was quite the interesting play.  Today, especially in the major cities there is the message of unifying in diversity.  Can uniting under this “banner” be consistent?  What if some decided that in their diversity they would not unify, because of their diversity? Therefore uniting under the banner of diversity cannot stay consistent in and of itself.  However in John’s revelation I love what Christ shows.  Christ gives him a picture of the nations of the world united under one banner.  These people were:

Uncountable people.  John saw a number of people such as could not be counted around the throne of God,    Heb 4:16 says “Let us then approach the throne of grace with confidence, so that we may receive mercy and find grace to help us in our time of need.”  Only God could gather such a crowd, as He is spectacle unlike any other.

2.     Unalike people.  John sees people “from every nation, tribe, people and language.”  Wow, that must have looked like an awesome sight.  John saw the nations of the world standing together, and no one was arguing, fighting, or even focusing on their “national pride.”

3.    Unashamed people.   These people were not serving, nor focusing on themselves but rather, “standing before the throne and in front of the Lamb…wearing white robes and were holding palm branches in their hands… crying out in a loud voice: “Salvation belongs to our God, who sits on the throne, and to the Lamb.”  “Paul said I am not ashamed of the gospel, because it is the power of God for the salvation of everyone who believes: first for the Jew, then for the Gentile.”  Paul like John saw a church unashamed to worship the Lamb of God, whose blood unites all true Christians.  Jesus died for ALL People, EVERYWHERE, and John sees ALL people on the earth represented at the Throne of Grace.  1 Cor. 1:22-24 “Jews demand miraculous signs and Greeks look for wisdom, but we preach Christ crucified: a stumbling block to Jews and foolishness to Gentiles, but to those whom God has called, both Jews and Greeks, Christ.”  My nationality, ethnicity, abilities, hobbies, etc… can never unite me with every nation, tongue and tribe, BUT MY JESUS CAN.  I often say in reference to my best friend Evans, we would not have ever formed a friendship based n common interests, but we are best of friends because of the blood of Jesus.

Uncountable people, unalike people, and unashamed people will be around the Throne One Great Day unified by the Lamb’s shed blood.  Will you be there worshipping an audience of ONE with the nations of the world?  John was alone on the Island of Patmos, but he saw unity in the heavens.  We are all the same (worshippers) and leveled at the Throne?    John saw it, what do you see or better yet what do you do with Christ’s Body?

title.rendered: What Is Your Attitude Towards Your Problems?

content.rendered:
Good morning,

A pastor placed this sign on his door, “If you have problems, come in and tell me all about them. If you don’t have any problems, come in and tell me how you avoid them.”

Problems: who needs them? What good are they? Can they be avoided altogether? Well, the truth of the matter is, problems are inevitable and are part and parcel of our life. Both believers and non believers have problems (big or small). And both don’t appreciate or enjoy going through their problems. In fact both, on many occasions don’t want to admit they have problems or want to talk about them. Too many Christians, admitting having problems of any kind is a sign of weakness. To some, having problems is associated to some sins (known or un-known). And to others, having problems is an indication that God has withdrawn from them and does not care anymore as He used to.

What is your attitude towards your problems?  I know you have some; some that you have talked about with others and maybe to God in prayer and those that are eating and killing you softly and don’t feel comfortable sharing with anyone. Whatever the case may be, you are scared and troubled about your problems. Thinking about them makes you sick, worried, and anxious and instead overcoming the problems, more problems develop and you become more overwhelmed.  What should you do? Where should you turn to? Here are some biblical guidelines for you to meditate on, adopt and apply in dealing with your problems:

First, you need to change your attitude toward your problems and trials that you face everyday. Look at your problems and trials as opportunity for growth, development and prosperity. Problems will destroy or make you. It all depends on your attitude and how you handle them.  Job had bigger problems. He believed that God was in control and that following his problems he would come forth a (golden) person. “He knows the way that I take; after he has tried me, I shall come forth like gold.” (Job 23:10) If you want to increase your value and be a “golden believer” adopt Job’s attitude.

Second, accept the Biblical fact that the righteous will have many afflictions in this life. Who you are, where you are, what you have or how spiritual you are, will not exempt you from experiencing affliction. “Many are the afflictions of the righteous, but God delivers them from them all.” (Psalms 34:19)

Third, endure problems, trials and temptations. “Blessed is the man who endures temptation; for when he has been tested and approved, he will receive the crown of life.” There is no promotion without problems. Those who want to prosper must learn to embrace problems, grow through them. You are either going through your problems or growing through them.

Last, take all your problems to Jesus. He is the answer to all our problems. He is seated upon His throne waiting for us. “Let us come boldly unto the throne of grace, that we may obtain mercy, and find grace to help in time of need.” (Hebrews 4:16) God bless you and give you peace and solutions to your problems today. Brother Boaz

Thanks
Evans

Good morning,

“Devote yourselves to prayer, being watchful and thankful.” Colossians 4:2

Recently my brother forwarded me an e-mail that our dad had written.  What my dad wrote shocked me, but at the same time made me very glad.  Sometimes you really don’t know how God is working, for me it seems many times, but behind the scenes God is doing things that can’t be seen by our sight.  I have prayed many times for my parents, and that God would work mightily in their lives.  I believe that God was showing how he heard my prayers all along and has been, and continues to work in His way and time. Here is that touching e-mail.

My job is going very well. We all had to pick our routes for the rest of the school year. When started back in Dec. they gave me a very nice route. Each driver picks according to seniority. I am #70 of 80 drivers. As you see 69 drivers pick before me. I thought some one would take my route away from me. I prayed to God and asked him to help me. If some one else took the route then it was meant for me to chose another route. You see I have learn to pray each day to thank him for all he has done for me. I also ask him to show me what path I should follow.  When it came time to pick the route I could not believe that no one took the route away from me.  I was able to get the same route. God has save my life many times. He must have a reason because I know I really don’t deserve all he has done for me.  We could never do enough to repay him. We can at least go to church once a week and thank him for all he has done for us.  Think, a couple of hours a week. We spend hours each week doing things for ourselves.  i believe we got to give something back. It seems all we do is take.  Please read this letter and tell me what you think of what I am saying.

I love you son.

Dad

In Colossians 4:2 Paul tells us to keep three important things in mind in light of your spiritual life which I think my dad also shared in his letter.  They are as follows:

Be Devoted to Prayer.  Anyone can say grace at a meal, or even mutter out a quick prayer before bed.  However devotion means time to something or to someone.  In this case Paul admonishes us to spend time in prayer with God showing our devotion to Him.  Are you spending time in your day in prayer?  When? Where?

2.    Be Watchful.  When we pray, we should feel comfortable enough to sit back and watch God work.  His answer may be yes, He may say wait and trust me, or He may say no to your request.  We are to be full of watching God work His will out in our lives, and in situations we are praying about.  But again it is relational with God.

3.    Be Thankful.  Many complain to Him, few thank Him.  When is the last time you came to God with a thanksgiving list instead of a shopping list or a complaint list?  I think my dad was pretty thankful for such a simple prayer, and had the right attitude when he wrote “You see I have learn to pray each day to thank him for all he has done for me.”

Are you devoted to prayer?  Are you watchful?  Are you thankful?

Until the nets are filled, Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Mistakes are inevitable occurrences in life. We all make mistakes deliberately, accidentally or unconsciously. Whatever the case may be, there are always consequences of our mistakes. In nearly all cases, the consequences are never pleasant or desirable. It is usually very hard to predict accurately what the consequences of our mistakes might be and how they will impact our life and the life of those around us.

I would like to refer you to two incidents in the Bible in which two good people made mistakes that bore very grave consequences that almost ruined or cost them their life and relationships. The first case is that of Esau, the eldest son of Isaac and the second is that of Joseph, the son of Jacob, Esau’s youngest brother. Esau sold his birthright. Joseph bragged arrogantly and foolishly to his jealous brothers and un-discerning parents about his future. He didn’t know how to keep secrets. He had a wide mouth and was full of youthful pride, arrogance, stupidity and immaturity. He was power hungry. His mistakes put him in the pit and prison in Egypt. God’s hands, however, lifted him from the prison and placed him in Pharaoh’s palace, and was later made ruler of Egypt. God reversed his misfortune to fortune. Joseph learned from his mistakes. He forgave his brothers

Esau too made a big mistake. He sold his birth right to his younger brother for a bowl of soup because he was hungry. That bad and permanent decision he made in order to satisfy a temporary need cost him a lifetime loss of riches, honor, and happiness. Besides, that mistake later created a wedge between him and his brother Jacob. The consequences of Esau’s mistake were grave. His hunger was genuine and he needed to satisfy it. He did. Only he did it the wrong way. If he had learnt to be patient, thoughtful, prayerful, wise, he still would have been able, by God’s help, to find a good, proven and acceptable solution for his hunger. The spirit of anger followed hunger as Esau tried to deal with the aftermath of his mistake. Anger and hunger, are two dangerous physical and emotional drivers that are responsible for a lot of mistakes people make every day in life and the consequences of those mistakes.

Can you think of a time or occasion when you made a mistake, for instance, by saying or doing the wrong thing simply because you were hungry for something or angry at someone or something? Are you aware of what your anger or hunger might have cost you? Yes, hunger and anger, if not dealt with the right way, can be very costly regardless of whether you are born again or not. Many marriages, for instance, have ended because of mistakes inspired and inflated by hunger and anger. Parents and their children have created emotional distance between them because of anger and hunger. Good friendships have dissolved because of anger and hunger. Many have lost good jobs and missed opportunities for promotion and advancement because they were angry at the boss, company or because they were hungry for more money, power and prestige and were not willing to wait for these things to arrive on God’s time at right place, the right way. Worse of all, many have sold their Christian birthright and heritage and lost all the blessings and privileges that accompany salvation because of being angry at God. Angry because of thinking that God forsook them in times of their desperate need.

Like Esau and Joseph, we sometimes make honest, but silly mistakes. Mistakes can cause misfortunes. Learn to avoid or minimize them. How? Prove all things. Scrutinize your thoughts, actions before you act. “…That you may prove what is that good, acceptable and perfect will of God.” Romans 12:2. Learn to forgive and to give. It is more blessed to forgive and receive than it is to be forgiven and be given.
“Forgiveness and giving, when practiced on a daily basis, are two practical activities that can stimulate amends, instigate reunions, and restore what was once wounded, lost or stolen.” Becky Tirabassi, “Change Your Life”. God bless you. Brother Boaz

Good morning,

“Therefore I say unto you, what things soever ye desire, when ye pray, believe that ye receive them, and ye shall have them.” Mark 11:24

Expectations create reality. God is a master builder, creator and communicator of positive expectations that create reality.
What do you do when faced with a mountain of problem? Desire God’s solution through prayer. Believe that that you’ve already received the answer. Be expectant! What you expect, will eventually become a reality.

In Luke 9:16, Jesus was faced with a big problem. There were over five thousand men plus women, children, his disciples and himself in a desert place who were hungry and there was no food and no place to buy any for them to eat. The disciples did not know what to do. They had no clue what to do, so they suggested that the people be sent away (hungry). Jesus objected. He refused to panic. He refused to run away from the problem. He believed there was a solution if only he would look at the right direction. While his disciples were getting more anxious and troubled and the people were getting more weary, Jesus was contemplating a plan. He was calm and very composed. He had peace. He didn’t let the problem destabilize him. Instead, he did something that surprised the disciples and the multitude; He took a little boy’s lunch (two small fishes and five loaves of bread) and turned them into abundant supply, more than enough to feed the people. How did he do it? Here is how:

“Then he took the five loaves and the two fishes, and looking up to heaven, he blessed them, and brake, and gave to the disciples to set before the multitude. And they did eat, and were all filled; and there was taken up of fragments that remained to them twelve baskets.”

Here are some observations about how Jesus handled the problem;
·    Instead of focusing on the problem, Jesus focused on the possibility.
·    He used the little that was available to make the much that was needed to feed the multitude.
·    He looked up to heaven, gave thanks and blessed the bread and the fishes
·    He gave to the disciples and commanded them to distribute. The miracle happened! There was more than enough for everybody, and more than enough left over. The problem was solved. The people rejoiced. The place became a historical sight.

You too can overcome your personal problems by observing the same principles. Learn to speak to God more about your problems and less to people, especially those who have no business knowing about your personal problems and who cannot help. Keep secrets. Be a possibilitarian not a problematarian! Think possibilities and expect miracles. God bless you. Boaz

content.rendered:
Good morning,

“Then, leaving her water jar, the woman went back to the town and said to the people.” (John 4:28)

In this story Jesus had an interaction with the women at the well.  This woman had a sexually sinful lifestyle.   First: Jesus began in the natural realm (v. 7). This woman was unregenerate, and the Bible tells us “the natural man receives not the things of the Spirit of God” (1 Corinthians 2:14). He therefore spoke of something she could relate to-water.   Second: Jesus swung the conversation to the spiritual realm (v. 10). He simply mentioned the things of God.  Jesus made the powerful statement saying, “If you knew the gift of God and who it is that asks you for a drink, you would have asked him and he would have given you living water.”  Third: Jesus brought conviction using the Law of God (vv. 16-18). Jesus gently spoke to her conscience by alluding to the fact that she had transgressed the Seventh of the Ten Commandments. He used the Law to bring “the knowledge of sin” (see Romans 3:19, 20).  This woman agreed with Jesus as to her sinful state and admitting that she had some “dirty water” in her bucket.  Fourth: Jesus revealed Himself to her (v. 26).  Once the Law has humbled the person, he is ready for grace.  Jesus revealed Himself to her as the only one that could purify the dirty water in her life as He made His identity as Messiah known to her.  However the question remains, why did this women leave behind her water bucket?

Perhaps she forgot it.  This woman had quite a conversion with Jesus and one that would change her life forever.  Perhaps in the midst of the conversation she ran back to tell the town about Jesus and simply forgot the water bucket (hence what she came there for).  Sometimes when something leaves us in awe we tend to forget the immediate.

2.    Maybe it was a gift to Jesus.  Jesus had spoken such words of truth to her that she had never heard before.  She was overwhelmed with awe after having Jesus reveal to her that He in fact was the Messiah she was waiting for standing before her.  Perhaps she felt that He gave her a gift in the encounter, and she gave him a gift in leaving the water bucket for him.

3.    She didn’t want it anymore.  This woman perhaps felt that water bucket filling was noting compared to what she just discovered in the Messiah.

4.    Her new life began the bucket for new water!  “Whoever believes in me, as the Scripture has said, streams of living water will flow from within him,” or in this case her!  She brought the message of the Messiah to her whole village and “Many of the Samaritans from that town believed in him because of the woman’s testimony, “He told me everything I ever did.”  And because of his words many more became believers. They said to the woman, “We no longer believe just because of what you said; now we have heard for ourselves, and we know that this man really is the Savior of the world.”  Jesus gave her beauty for ashes.

Is your life an empty bucket of temporary satisfaction, or one in which flows streams of living water from within him?  The Gospel is not to stay in the bucket of our lives, but is to be poured out to the thirsty.

“Then he said to his disciples, “The harvest is plentiful but the workers are few.  Ask the Lord of the harvest, therefore, to send out workers into his harvest field.” (Matt 9:37-38)

Alarming Statistics… (Living Waters)

·    “In his book The Coming Revival, Bill Bright reported that “only two percent of believers in America regularly share their faith in Christ with others” (NewLife Publications, p. 65).
·    “A soul at the altar does not generate much excitement in some circles because we realize approximately ninety-five out of every hundred will not become integrated into the church. In fact, most of them will not return for a second visit.” Charles E. Hackett, the Division of Home Missions National Director for a leading U.S. denomination.

This happened despite the usual intense follow-up.”

Who do you know that isn’t saved, family member, friend, co-worker, etc….  Now imagine them in the Lake of Fire for all eternity.  To think of their fate should cause your heart to feel what Jesus felt looking at those people.  He knew that He was the Divine Shepherd they needed and without Him they would perish on the Day of Judgment.  Laborers would need to go to them for the crop will be plentiful; many people will be ready to be “reaped” into the kingdom.  Luke writes of this account but adds that Jesus said, “Go! I am sending you out like lambs among wolves (10:3).”  He told them not only to pray, but also to GO thus beginning to answer the very prayer they were to pray.  “We all, like sheep, have gone astray, each of us has turned to his own way; and the LORD has laid on him the iniquity of us all.”  A.W. Pink said, “It is true that [many] are praying for worldwide revival.  But it would be more timely, and more scriptural, for prayer to be made to the Lord of the harvest, that He would raise up and trust forth laborers who would fearlessly and faithfully preach those truths which are calculated to bring about a revival.”

Application:  Look at the shepherd-less (the unsaved) both those you know and the stranger and see them through Christ’s eyes.  By compassion PRAY and GO, they need you NOW!

title.rendered: I Will Be With You Says The Lord

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Joshua 1:9, “Have I not commanded you? Be strong and of good courage; do not be afraid, nor be dismayed, for the LORD your God is with you wherever you go.”

In this life we live in, we need company. We know that we cannot make it alone. Just because we don’t want to be alone does not mean we just need people to help us in one way or another, we may just need company. If you look at a child who may be terrified, a parent’s presence is enough to calm him or her down. He or she may not look to the parent to take the fear away, they feel the presence of a parent is enough to overcome fear.

What about us believers, at times we are not looking for answers, we are looking for someone to be with us. Their presence is enough to make us face what we could be running away from. In Joshua’s case, he always had Moses with him and because of that, he was strong and courageous fighting in battles. When Moses was gone, the Lord encouraged him of His presence, He might have seen that He needed His presence now more than ever. And the Lord said to him, “Be strong and courageous. Do not be terrified; do not be discouraged”, To me these were not things Joshua was to be given, these were things that could come about because of God’s promised presence. Just like a child who gains peace and confidence, not because of what the parent (s) give him at the time of weakness and fear but what comes about because of their presence. Three times in Joshua 1, God assures Joshua of His presence, Joshua 1:5,”… as I was with Moses, so I will be with you, 1:9, “for the LORD your God is with you”, 1:17, “…only the Lord your God be with you”. God’s presence alone was enough to take away fear and give him courage to go forward. God was with Joseph in the absence of his father Jacob. Jacob did not even know what became of his son but God was with him in the pit, in portiphar’s house, in jail and even on the throne. God was with Daniel in the lion’s den, he was with Shadrach, Meshack and Abednego in the fire, he was with David when he was running away from Saul, he was with Jonah when he tried to flee from His presence, He said to Abraham, in Genesis 26:3, “dwell in this land, and I will be with you and bless you. He told Jacob in Genesis 31:3, Return to the land of your fathers and to your family, and I will be with you.” He told Gideon in Judges 6:16, Surely I will be with you, and you shall defeat the Midianites as one man”. What do all these people have in common, they were all afraid and their situations did not change but God’s presence was with them through it all.

He is Immanuel God with us. He is Jehovah Shammah, the ever present God. He is present our kids even when they are not with us. He is present in our spouses even in our absence. He is present in us in our jobs when we get overwhelmed. What a joy to know that He is ever present. He does not need to come, He is already here and how He would speak to us like He spoke to Joshua, “Have I not commanded you? Be strong and of good courage; do not be afraid, nor be dismayed, for the LORD your God is with you wherever you go.” We don’t need Him to come and solve, His presence is enough to solve so remember, don’t be discouraged or afraid, He is with you. Blessings Ev

Good morning,

Hebrews 6:9-19, “And so, after he had patiently endured, he obtained the promise”

I have learnt that patience is not taught in a classroom, it is taught and mastered in the sea of life. A dangerous prayer one can make is, “God teach me patience”, it’s a prayer for those who know the end result but do not know the process but are willing to stick it out. What happens when you are dealing with something that requires patience, for me many times I try to find an alternative. Driving on the road and there is traffic, hey, I will try and find another road. The problem I found avoiding what I should have dealt with is that I got lost. Some things looked familiar as I made that choice only to find I was going further and further away from my destination and in the long run “I wish I knew” runs through my head. When God is teaching us patience, the test comes always as an open book test. To make it interesting, if you fail the test, you can take over and over again. What does this tell us, God is also very patient with His children. Can you imagine a teacher giving an open book test, all the answers are there but the student keeps failing that test? After a while his or her patience will run out but God is patient with us. He was patient with the Israelites who complained and murmured, He was patient with Gideon who kept on asking for a sign. He was patient with David who was weak when it came to women, He was very patient with Peter who kept on messing up things. He who invented patience knows how to be patient. Point to make, faith goes with patience.

As Paul was writing to the Hebrews, he recalls on how Abraham had hope and patience to inherit the promise God had promised him. He is encouraging us to do what some people like Abraham did before the promise was fulfilled, Hebrews 6:11&12, “And we desire that each one of you show the same diligence to the full assurance of hope until the end, that you do not become sluggish, but imitate those who through faith and patience inherit the promises”. Some of these people are the open books we have to teach us how to endure through faith till the promise comes. Their promises are the result of their faith and patience and we look at it and say if they did it, we too can do it by God’s grace. Everyone has a dream, promises, desires, some of them have to come to pass but there are some that have not. In the valley of decision calls for an action, “should I stay on this road I already know of, wait patiently to receive the promise or should I take a back road hoping to lead me there? Abraham took the road God had set for him, there were a lot of traffic and I bet many times he thought of taking the back roads as the traffic was not moving but faith kept him on that road. Hebrews 10:35&36, “Cast not therefore your confidence with has great recompense of reward. For you are in need of patience that after you have done the will of God, you might receive the promise”. The key to fulfilling the promise is sticking with the will of God in a situation till the end. Your confidence and my confidence in Christ has great reward because when we have confidence in someone that they can and will do it, regardless of when they do it, we will still patiently wait for them to do it. Patience is a must to every wise man therefore we are in need of it. I don’t want it but I need it ’cause it teaches me to be in the will of God gearing me to the promise. In the end when you look back you begin to see why patience was a must in your journey to the promise. In the valley of decision though hard, I will stick to the road I started on based on His will. I will be tempted to take the back roads but I will learn to stay on the main road. He is patient therefore He will help me be patient. If I fail, I can take the test again, I will utilize the open book in the valley of decision. After we have done the will of God… Blessings Evans (I had shared this devotion earlier in 2003)

title.rendered: A Husband Enjoying His Wife’s Body, by Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

How beautiful your sandaled feet, O prince’s daughter!  Your graceful legs are like jewels, the work of a craftsman’s hands.  Your navel is a rounded goblet that never lacks blended wine.  Your waist is a mound of wheat encircled by lilies.  Your breasts are like two fawns, twins of a gazelle.  Your neck is like an ivory tower.  Your eyes are the pools of Heshbon by the gate of Bath Rabbim.  Your nose is like the tower of Lebanon looking toward Damascus.  Your head crowns you like Mount Carmel.  Your hair is like royal tapestry; the king is held captive by its tresses.   How beautiful you are and how pleasing, O love, with your delights!  Your stature is like that of the palm, and your breasts like clusters of fruit.   I said, “I will climb the palm tree; I will take hold of its fruit.” May your breasts be like the clusters of the vine, the fragrance of your breath like apples, and your mouth like the best wine.”  (Song of Solomon 7:1 – 9)

Songs of Solomon or Song of Songs is perhaps one of the most controversial books in Scripture because of its erotic language use.  One camp feels that the book describes ones relationship with the Lord, while the other sees Solomon is sharing his passionate feelings toward his wife, his lover. My personal perspective is that of the later one that this describes passionate, romantic, and erotic love shared between husband and wife.

Start at the Bottom.  Solomon praised his wife starting with her sandaled feet, and then moved to her legs.  Wives enjoy when their husbands notice the little things about them even their feet and legs.  Husbands remember that God brought those feet and legs at one time to you, and you are to keep those feet and legs with you in ONENESS with you.  Praise your wife (not in an idolatrous way) for these features.

2.    Continue in the Middle.  Solomon praised his wife’s navel, waist and breasts.  Many men are drawn away by the mid features of other women, but God desires that our wives be the only source of satisfaction.  Solomon writes is Proverbs 5:19 – 20, “A loving doe, a graceful deer- may her breasts satisfy you always, may you ever be captivated by her love. Why be captivated, my son, by an adulteress? Why embrace the bosom of another man’s wife?  Why not compliment your wife for her mid features today.

3.    Don’t forget the top.  Solomon praised his lover for her neck, hair, eyes, mouth, nose and breath.  When you look at your wife what do you see.  Are you captivated by her beauty?  Are you drawn away by her unique features above her shoulders? Most men are drawn only to those features that are from the waist to the shoulders.  Even Solomon mentioned his wife’s breasts three times.  It seems like he had a thing going on!  However, he shared his intimate words with his wife.

How beautiful you are and how pleasing, O love, with your delights. “…your breasts like clusters of fruit.   I said, “I will climb the palm tree; I will take hold of its fruit.  He described his wife to her from the bottom to top.  He was drawn away, captivated, enamored by her beauty that was for his pleasure and to her delight.  What wife would not like to be complimented by her husband?  Husbands let’s make sure that we are the ones complimenting our wives, because we don’t want someone else to do it for us.  Our wives need to have our voices in their ears praising their beauty and, not another voice.  Have you complimented your wife lately?  Enjoy your wife and let her enjoy you as well.  And perhaps both you and your wife have features that have aged a little.  Remember DON’T TRY and pick another rose just because your petals don’t look like they used to.  Your wife is the rose that God picked for you, so water, shine, and nurture her with your words.  Do you date your wife?  Why not take her out date, like when you first met.

Good morning,

1Samuel 17:45, “…You come to me with a sword, with a spear, and with a javelin. But I come to you in the name of the Lord hosts, the God of the armies of Israel, whom you have defied”

To be associated with the new birth calls for us to operate on the greater dimensions for we are not who we used to be but new 2Cor 5:17, “If any man be in Christ, He is a new creation, old things have passed away, behold everything is become new”. This is the time where we are changed inside out for our Spirits are new and with time the our entire being is changed. I used to think that the moment someone got saved they were complete and could cry out holy until I understood that the only new thing in me was Spirit (heart) and now the rest of the being has to be worked on to become what it was not.

As we move to greater dimensions, how we think, act and talk does contribute significantly to our walk with God for we have dropped the old man and put on the new man Jesus Christ. In 1Samuel 15, Saul is rejected as the king but still operates in his kingship for his rejection was not to bring him down from the throne but allow the presence of the Lord to depart from him, in Chapter 16, David a young boy has been anointed the new young king. He is not there yet but he has confidence in God. In chapter 17 marks one of the greatest stories about David’s life when he comes to the battlefield and finds no one fighting but one huge dude talking and blaspheming the God of Israel. David is listening and recalling, though he knows that he is just but a young man who has never been in the army, has no training of any kind, cannot even fit in the armor and combat gear, cannot even carry a sword for it’s to heavy for him, he understands that what people see in him is old news for the one inside of him is the good news. David is despised by his brothers for he is expected to take care of the sheep and also the fact that he is a young lad, the giant has also despised him because he is a young man and has no weapon in his hand. Something interesting, the bible takes time to describe how Goliath was dressed and when you read it, you find that this guy was ready for war, he had trained himself, got the best weapons, had the body for it, the words from his mouth could kill a fly and yet a young boy shows up from the field, finds himself in the battle ground un prepared. I thank God that though I may look unprepared, He is prepared and the way every one might expect Him to fight may not be the way He will choose to fight.

1Samuel 17:45, “The David to the Philistine, “You come to me with a sword, with a spear, and with a javelin. But I come to you in the name of the Lord hosts, the God of the armies of Israel, whom you have defied”. I have come in the name that is above every name he says. You may look that strong and macho but I have to let you know that whoever is in me is greater than he that is in the world. You may come to me in the name of fear, brokenness, doubt, depression, confusion, sickness, anger but I come to you in the name of Lord of host whom you have defied. The bible says in 1John 3:8, “… for this purpose the son of God was manifested that He might destroy the works of the devil”, amen. title.rendered: Is There JOY In Your Marriage?, By Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

“Enjoy life with your wife, whom you love, all the days of this meaningless life that God has given you under the sun-all your meaningless days. For this is your lot in life and in your toilsome labor under the sun.”  (Ecclesiastes 9:9)

“You don’t know my wife.”  Perhaps this is a common statement made by many husbands carries the weight of a negative expression.  And perhaps, you’re right, another person doesn’t “know” your wife, but are they supposed to know her like you do?  God has not called anyone except for you to leave and cleave to the women that you married.  Marriage is definitely under fire in these days.  Hence the statement “you don’t know my wife,” should be an extreme positive and not a negative.  Solomon writes of the futility of life, and hence because it is her today gone tomorrow, one should rejoice in one’s marriage, instead of being depressed in one’s marriage if marriage is done God’s way.  Solomon shares the following points in how one can rejoice in marriage:

Live Joyfully.  This speaks of being full of Joy (JOY-FULLY).  Joy is the fruit of being in the presence of the Lord (Psalm 16:11).  Paul writes of the fruit of the Spirit one of which is JOY (Gal. 5:22).  The popular question had been “are you living a purpose driven life,” however I think the better question is, “Are you living a “presence driven life.”  When two people in a marriage are both spending time in the Lord’s presence all that needs to be done is to bring all that JOY together, to live joyfully.  Are you and your wife spending DAILY time in His presence?

2.    Relate with Joy together.  The key word here is WITH.  God’s desire for marriage is that not only do both husband and wife spend time in the presence of the Lord thus creating a dovetail of like-mindedness, but husbands are privileged to do this WITH their very best friend.  I heard an acronym for J.O.Y., which stood for Jesus Others You!  Jesus must come first, others, in this case your wife is second on the top of the others list, and you are last but not forgotten.

3.    Love Your Wife.  Why did you get married?  People have many reasons, and many which are selfish.  Paul however tells us, “Husbands, love your wives, just as Christ loved the church and gave himself up for her.”  In the Garden of Eden Eve ate the fruit and therefore deserved to die.  God, “Adam I have to kill her.”  Adam replied, “No God, please take my life instead.  I will die in her place” Now of course the account didn’t really lay out this way with the first Adam, but it did with the second Adam.  Christ gave His life for His beloved bride, and modeled what men are to do for their wives.  Jesus said, “No greater love is there than this, that a man lay his life down for his friends.”  Men our wives are to be our very best friend, and therefore in one word we are to show them love through SACRIFCE!

When one lives JOYFULLY, relates WITH joy together, and loves SACRIFICIALLY, the principle remains that one can live a full life with ones’ life marked by JOY IN MARRIAGE!  No go live with His Joy in your marriage, it’s really possible!

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Wanted to share with you a devotion I did back in 2002.

Ecclesiastes 9:10, “Whatever your hand finds to do, do it with your might; for there is no work or device or knowledge or wisdom in the grave where you are going”

We all get busy as we approach the end of year, a lot to be done, dead lines, a lot requires your attention, strength and abilities. This is the time you get overwhelmed by the many things you have work on. You put so much effort to bring all your work under control but before you can finish dealing with this, here comes another one. It’s so overwhelming that you are loosing your composure and patience, people are getting on your nerves and you want to scream, throw things around, tempted to curse or you’ve already done it. To sum your condition up, I would say that you are disoriented.

Psalm 118:24, “This is the day that the Lord has made; we (I) rejoice and be glad in it”. we are in a new day, a day of new beginnings, a fresh day where we receive not the yesterday’s mercies but today’s, fresh mercies to keep us. Confess with me this morning that this is the day that the Lord has made. Regardless of what awaits me at work, at home or whatever, I confess that line. If you confess that line and you believe it, then you are ready to move to the next line. In place of “We will” lets use “I will” and say I will rejoice and be glad in it. That sounds so good and rich. You’ve heard me say this, “how you start your day has the ability to affect how you will finish it”. Starting the day does not go by feeling but by choice (I will). How will you choose to start your day?

The bible is very clear when it gives it’s message without beating about the bush, in Eccle 9:10, “whatever your hand finds to do, do it with your might”. Actually I could stop there for it is well said but I would present to us that people would interpret it as “whatever your hands finds to do, if you like it, do it with your might”. The bible says whatever your hand finds to do, hey do it with all you’ve got, put your strength into it, wisdom, skills, give it the best shot whether you like it or not. Because it’s not a matter of liking, but being faithful. Faithfulness causes you to be content and contentment causes you to be comfortable. As you are comfortable and God can trust you with the little, God will open doors for you to be ruler over much. It’s in the process of being faithful in the little that causes your character to be enlarged for the greater things. When Joseph was in Portiphar’s house, he knew that his dream was not yet fulfilled and therefore being in that house was a preparing ground for if he could be faithful even in that which was not his place, God could trust him with the greater things in the due time. We see him thrown in prison and instead of complaining and murmuring, he takes the advantage of being humbled and there again he becomes faithful even with that which he is not happy about. Phil 2:14, “Do everything without murmurings and disputing”, Galatians 6:9, “And let us not be weary in well doing: for in due season we shall reap, if we faint not”. Have you been waiting for a pat in the back, to be affirmed, to be talked well off, to be thanked? in this life we are living in, very few will appreciate what you do but guess what, God is seeing all your hard work and as the bible says, don’t stop or get tired of doing good to your colleagues, customers, boss, people you interact with for there is coming a time that you will reap but only if you faint not . When God begins to reward you because of your faithfulness, it may not come from the people you helped for God may use different channels and instead of you fighting your way to the next level, your character of faithfulness will fight for you. How did the king get to know about Joseph? one of the servants who was with Joseph in prison put a good word to the king about Joseph’s faithfulness and how God had favored him. Now the servant did not leave the prison and say this, he forgot about Joseph for a long time until the king had a dream that troubled him and they needed someone and there was Joseph. This was Joseph’s due season of reaping for he fainted not.

Set up yourself ready for the day, set up goals, know that everything is not going to go as planned but don’t be disoriented and out of control for God is in control. Look to the one who brought Joseph to the top and ask Him to give you guidance, wisdom, strength, courage, skills to work hard and smart, effectively and teach you how to be faithful. Be in a position to make a difference even if it means doing it without the support of the rest. Set up something that will always remind you of why you are there and go forward for as the verse we read from the beginning concludes, “for there is no work or device or knowledge or wisdom in the grave where you are going”. You and I have potentials we are not going to need when this life is over, let’s put them into use now and we will set up an example to the rest. We need a resume update, a resume that will speak on our behalf. Joseph’s faithfulness caused him to have a powerful resume that he needed not to defend himself for his resume did the job. Charisma may put someone on top, but character will sustain them on top so be faithful till the end.
